docs.lead_paragraph: Still hoping to undermine support for a health care overhaul, Republican House members are preparing for town-hall-style meetings in their home districts during the Veterans Day recess between now and early next week. Representative Mike Pence of Indiana, chairman of the House Republican Conference, has issued 16 pages of talking points urging fellow Republicans to use the recess to tell their constituents that the House bill would destroy the economy and the health insurance system.
docs.abstract: Republican House members, hoping to undermine support for health care overhaul, prepare for town-hall-style meetings in home districts during recess; Democrats will be out pushing bill at their own meetings and news conferences (S)
docs.snippet: Still hoping to undermine support for a health care overhaul, Republican House members are preparing for town-hall-style meetings in their home districts during the Veterans Day recess between now and early next week.     Representative Mike Pence of...

docs.lead_paragraph: When his car repair shop's health insurance premiums doubled between 2000 and 2002, David White saw the problem as akin to a sputtering engine. So he got under the hood of the state's health system and tried to fix it. Seven years later, Mr. White is on seven health advocacy and improvement boards, has helped devise the state's public insurance plan and has a library of health care books and research papers. He spent so much time on the issue that his business suffered. But he still has no health insurance for himself or his lone remaining mechanic, an experience that is emblematic of his state's.

headline.main: Maine Finds a Health Care Fix Elusive

docs.abstract: Maine legislators have tried for decades to fix health care system but premiums are still among least affordable in nation; health care spending per person is among highest, and hospital emergency rooms are among most crowded; Maine's history is cautionary tale for national health reform; state could never determine how to slow spiraling increases in medical costs, hobbling its efforts to offer more people insurance coverage; photo (M)
docs.snippet: In a cautionary tale for national reform, overhauls to the Maine system have done little more than solve one problem while worsening another.

docs.lead_paragraph: Intel's push into the health care arena has the company going some unusual places.

headline.main: Intel Sells Its Own Reader for the Health Care Market

docs.abstract: Digging deeper into the health care market, Intel has started selling its own Intel Reader device aimed at people who struggle to read printed material.
docs.snippet: Digging deeper into the health care market, Intel has started selling its own Intel Reader device aimed at people who struggle to read printed material.

docs.lead_paragraph: As some of you will recall, I have been following the progress of (and offering advice to) Debbie Dusenberry, the owner of a home-furnishing and gift store in Kansas called Curious Sofa. You can read "When Passion Meets Math" to see how Ms. Dusenberry built her store, garnered lots of media attention for her merchandising, ran smack into the Great Recession and began the journey from artist to businesswoman. This small-business journey is far more common than most people understand. Ms. Dusenberry is so good at the artistry that she is envied by other owners, one of whom has called her "retail royalty." But as you will see in a moment, her retail reality is very different.

headline.main: The Dusenberry Diary: Living the Dream? Or Just Living?

docs.abstract: The reality of one small-business owner's journey.
docs.snippet: The reality of one small-business owner's journey.
